intro: Secale triflorum, commonly known as the three-flowered rye, is a flowering plant in the grass family Poaceae. It is native to Europe and parts of Asia and is characterized by its slender, grass-like leaves and small, clustered inflorescences. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and produces three to five spikelets per stem. It prefers moist, well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along stream banks. Due to its historical use in agriculture and its ornamental value, it has been cultivated in various regions for both practical and aesthetic purposes.
